w:r.w:t: Here is the architectural blueprint for building this with high confidence.
You need models small enough to run on a user’s laptop GPU (via WebGL) but smart enough to catch artifacts. Do not use ResNet-50 (too big).
We will use three lightweight analyzers that "vote" on whether a video is fake.
Look for visual glitches (blur around ears, mismatched earrings, weird teeth).
It’s incredibly fast and optimized for mobile devices.
to shrink the model size from ~20MB to ~4MB without losing much accuracy.
Detect the "checkerboard artifacts" left by Up-Sampling in GANs and Diffusion models. Humans can't see these, but math can.
Convert the face image to grayscale $\rightarrow$ Apply
$\rightarrow$ Feed the frequency spectrum image into a tiny classifier.
AI generators struggle to replicate the exact high-frequency noise of a real camera sensor.
. Real human skin changes color imperceptibly as blood pumps (subtle green channel fluctuation). AI faces usually do not have a heartbeat, or it is irregular.
This is your "High Confidence" signal. If the video is 4k resolution but has zero pulse signal, it is 99% likely AI.
Since you want "pure code" (no servers), the browser
Do not use TensorFlow.js for production video analysis if you can avoid it. ONNX Runtime is generally faster and supports models trained in PyTorch, which is the industry standard for research.
You cannot rely on the HTML <video> tag alone. You need to extract raw frame data efficiently. FFmpeg compiled to WebAssembly allows you to decode video frames directly in memory.
It is Google's ultra-optimized library. It runs at 60+ FPS in the browser. Do not write your own face detector; you will not beat this.
Before you write a line of web code, you must train your models correctly.
Web videos are compressed. If your AI only knows "clean" data, it will think
YouTube video is fake because of compression artifacts. You must teach it the difference between "compression noise" and "AI noise."
Step 2: Building the Frame Extraction Pipeline (Client Side)
You don't analyze every frame (that kills the CPU).
Decode frame at t=0s, t=0.5s, t=1.0s.
Push these bitmaps to an OffscreenCanvas (to avoid UI lag).
This is the hardest but most impressive part to build in pure code.
Use MediaPipe to get the landmarks for the cheeks and forehead.
For each frame, calculate the average
pixel intensity in the cheek area.
Store this value in an array signal[].
After 5 seconds of video (approx 150 frames), run a
on signal[] (allow frequencies 0.7Hz to 4Hz, which matches human heart rates of 42-240 BPM).
If the resulting signal is "flat" or "pure random noise," score it as
. Real blood flow has a distinct wave pattern.
If a video has flashing lights (like a club), the rPPG heart detector will fail.
Add a code check for "high variance in average brightness" and disable the rPPG module for those clips.
Video processing in a browser eats RAM.
Manually dispose of your Tensors! In TensorFlow.js/ONNX, doing tensor.dispose() is mandatory. If you forget, the browser tab will crash after 10 seconds of video.
Running three Neural Networks in Chrome will heat up a user's phone.
. This runs your heavy math on a separate thread so the "Stop" button doesn't freeze while the AI is thinking.
This script transforms a video frame into a
. This is the exact visualization forensic experts use to spot the "checkerboard" artifacts left by AI upsampling layers (GANs and Diffusion models) that are invisible to the naked eye.
You will need opencv-python, numpy, and matplotlib.
Generates a Frequency Spectrum Fingerprint from an image/frame.
image_path (str): Path to the input image/frame.
apply_hpf (bool): If True, applies a High Pass Filter first to remove
structural facial details and isolate "noise" artifacts.
# We only need luminance to detect structural artifacts.
print(f"Error: Could not load image at {image_path}")
# This removes the face itself (eyes, nose) and leaves only the
# fine-grain noise where AI artifacts hide.
# We subtract a Gaussian Blur version from the original
# 4. Shift the Zero-Frequency component to the center
# By default, FFT puts low frequencies in the corner. We want them in the middle.
# Real signals have a huge dynamic range. We use 20*log to make faint artifacts visible.
# We add 1e-7 to avoid log(0) errors.
plt.title('Input (High Pass Filtered)' if apply_hpf else 'Input Image')
# Replace 'test_face.jpg' with a frame extracted from your video
How to Read the "Fingerprints" (The Secret Sauce)
When you run this code, you will see a "heat map" in the right panel. Here is how to interpret it like an expert:
or a starburst fading smoothly from the center (low frequency) to the edges (high frequency).
Nature is chaotic. Cameras record light in a way that distributes noise randomly. There are no sharp, geometric lines in the spectrum.

If you see a regular grid of bright spots, that is the "heartbeat" of the Convolutional Neural Network. It happens because AI generates images by "Upsampling" (stretching) small noise tensors into big images. This stretching leaves a mathematical grid pattern that the AI cannot erase.
Why the "High Pass Filter" (HPF) is Crucial
In the code, I included apply_hpf=True.
The FFT is dominated by the big shapes (the shape of the head, the eyes). The spectrum just looks like a bright blob in the middle.
We delete the face. We keep only the
. This makes the AI artifacts pop out like a sore thumb in the frequency plot.
